content:
I am a PhD candidate in Electrical and Computer Engineering at University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. I am a part of the DEPEND group at CSL and am advised by Prof. Ravishankar K. Iyer. My research leverages machine learning to understand neurological disorders and to develop tools for diagnosing and treating them. For my disseration, I have worked on Alzheimer’s disease and epilepsy in collaboration with Dr. Gregory Worrell (Mayo Clinic), Prof. Michal Kucewicz (Mayo Clinic), Prof. Prashanthi Vemuri (Mayo Clinic), and Dr. David Jones (Mayo Clinic). I have also worked with Dr. Jasmohan Bajaj (VCU) on analysing the relationship between gut microbiome, liver cirrhosis, and cognitive decline.
I graduated with a B.Tech. and M.Tech. in Electrical Engineering from Indian Institute of Technology, Bombay. I specialised in Communications and Signal Processing. My thesis was with Prof. Vivek Borkar on topics in semi-supervised learning and resource allocation.
I am broadly interested in topics at the intersection of machine learning, neurology, and neuroscience. My goal is to develop and apply machine learning techniques to (i) delineate relationships among brain structure and activity, brain disorders, and cognition; and (ii) develop tools for assisting clinicians in disease diagnosis and intervention.
Recent News
08/2022: Awarded the Young Investigator Award at AES 2022 Annual Meeting. 06/2022: Our Journal of Hepatology 2022 paper was chosen as a landmark paper by the European Association for the Study of the Liver. 02/2022: Our work on using deep learning to identify brain structures that explain heterogeneity in cognitive aging got accepted in NeuroImage. 11/2021: Our work on differences between stool and saliva microbiome in predicting cirrhosis got published in the Journal of Hepatology. 11/2021: Awarded Paul D. Doolen Scholarship for the Study of Aging. Show more09/2021: Our work on an RL-based Alzheimer’s disease progression model got accepted at NeurIPS 2021. 09/2021: Our work on the effect of cognitive task on biomarkers of SOZ localization is published in Epilepsia. 08/2021: Attended the Center for Brains, Minds, and Machines Summer School 2021 in Woods Hole, MA. 04/21: Received the Elsa and Floyd Dunn Award. 06/20: Our work on gender differences in the gut microbiome of cirrhosis patients is published in the Journal of Hepatology. 05/20: Received the Mavis Future Faculty Fellowship. 03/20: Awarded Rambus Fellowship in ECE. 03/20: Our paper on predicting cognition trajectory got accepted at ISBI 2020 for Oral Presentation. Link. 12/19: CSL News article covering our work on Alzheimer’s disease was voted top story of the year. 10/19: Our paper on finding electrophysiogically active electrodes got published in Nature Scientific Reports. Link.
summary: I am a PhD candidate in Electrical and Computer Engineering at University of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign. I am a part of the DEPEND group at CSL and am advised by Prof. Ravishankar K.
title: Krishnakant V. Saboo

content:
This course was designed to provide an intuition for the fundamentals of basic machine learning models to students who have a high school level background in maths. It has over 12 hrs of lecture material along with an assignment for each lecture. Please find the lectures below. Feel free to reach out to me with any questions or suggestions or if you want access to the assignments!
Lecture 1: Maths review Lecture 2: k-Nearest Neighbor, Bayes Risk, Performance Metrics Lecture 3: Linear and Logistic Regression Lecture 4: Support Vector Machines, Random Forest Lecture 5: Clustering (k-Means, Gaussian Mixture Model) Lecture 6: Principal Component Analysis Thanks to Tejal, Irena, Thanh, Abhi, Michelle for their enthusiastic participation in the course. Special thanks to Prakruthi for her feedback in developing the material!
summary: This course was designed to provide an intuition for the fundamentals of basic machine learning models to students who have a high school level background in maths. It has over 12 hrs of lecture material along with an assignment for each lecture.
title: Machine Learning Summer Course 2020
